SubTopics: Find the greatest common factor of two whole numbers less than or equal to 100 and the least common multiple of two whole numbers less than or equal to 12. Use the distributive property to express a sum of two whole numbers 1–100 with a common factor as a multiple of a sum of two whole numbers with no common factor.
Content: Which expression has the same value as 54 + 24?

SubTopics: Write and evaluate numerical expressions involving whole-number exponents.
Content: An expression is shown.
Using a base and an exponent, write an expression that is equivalent to the one shown.

SubTopics: Understand signs of numbers in ordered pairs as indicating locations in quadrants of the coordinate plane; explain that when two ordered pairs differ only by signs, the locations of the points are related by reflections across one or both axes.
Content: The point (–2, 6) is plotted on a coordinate plane.
Which statements are true?
Select the TWO statements that are true.

A.Choice: The reflection point across the y-axis is (2, 6).

B.Choice: The reflection point across the y-axis is (2, –6).

C.Choice: The reflection point across the y-axis is (–2, –6).

D.Choice: The reflection point across the x-axis is (2, 6).

E.Choice: The reflection point across the x-axis is (2, –6).

F.Choice: The reflection point across the x-axis is (–2, –6).

SubTopics: Identify a statistical question as one that anticipates variability in the data related to the question and accounts for it in the answers.
Content: Which question is a statistical question?

A.Choice: Which students in an elementary school class can speak another language?

B.Choice: How many students in a middle school class like each type of food?

C.Choice: Which elementary classes is the principal visiting this week?

D.Choice: How many students are in a middle school?

SubTopics: Fluently divide multi-digit numbers using the standard algorithm.
Content: What is the value of this expression?

SubTopics: Fluently add, subtract, multiply, and divide multi-digit decimals using the standard algorithm for each operation.
Content: A baker mixes 42.68 grams of flour and 19.125 grams of sugar in a bowl. The baker then uses 52.76 grams of the mixture in a cake.
How many grams of the mixture does the baker still have?

SubTopics: Define the absolute value of a rational number as its distance from 0 on the number line; interpret absolute value as magnitude for a positive or negative quantity in a real-world situation.
Content: Which number is closest to zero on a number line?

SubTopics: Write an inequality of the form x > c, x ≥ c, x < c, or x ≤ c to represent a constraint or condition in a real-world or mathematical problem. Show that inequalities of the form x > c, x ≥ c, x < c, or x ≤ c have infinitely many solutions; represent solutions of such inequalities on number line diagrams.
Content: Graph the inequality that shows all the possible values of –1 > x.
Select the correct ray to represent the inequality on the number line.
Select the correct place on the number line to begin graphing the inequality on the number line.

SubTopics: Identify when two expressions are equivalent (i.e., when the two expressions name the same number regardless of which value is substituted into them).
Content: Use the information provided to answer Part A and Part B for this question.
A student makes two statements.

:box:Statement 1: 2x – 5 + 6 = 2x – 11 because the sum of 5 and 6 is 11.

Statement 2: 2x – 5 + 6 = 8x – 5 because the sum of 2x and 6 is 8x.
Evaluate the expressions for x = 10 to show that Statement 1 and Statement 2 are incorrect.
Explain why the student's reasoning in Statement 1 is incorrect.
Explain why the student's reasoning in Statement 2 is incorrect.

SubTopics: Identify when two expressions are equivalent (i.e., when the two expressions name the same number regardless of which value is substituted into them).
Content: Use the information provided to answer Part A and Part B for this question.
Points R and T are plotted on a coordinate grid.
problems/COG6M/media/10a.jpg
In right triangle RST, point T is graphed at (2, –3), and point R is graphed at (–1,1).
Which coordinate pair describes the location of point S?
Triangle MRT is graphed with point M at (–4, –3).
What is the length, in units, of side MT?

SubTopics: Solve unit rate problems including those involving unit pricing and constant speed.
Content: Use the information provided to answer Part A through Part D for this question.
The table shows the number of words four students can type in a given amount of time.
problems/COG6M/media/11a.jpg
Which student can type the FEWEST number of words in 60 minutes?
How many words could students X and Y type together in 2 hours?
Student Z is typing a document with 5,454 words. How many minutes will it take this student to type this document?
How many more words can Student Y type in 20 minutes compared to Student W?

SubTopics: Solve unit rate problems including those involving unit pricing and constant speed.
Find a percent of a quantity as a rate per 100 (e.g., 30% of a quantity means 30/100 times the quantity); solve problems involving finding the whole, given a part and the percent.
Content: Use the information provided to answer Part A and Part B for this question.
Volunteers go to a park to plant trees and build benches. A total of 32 volunteers go to the park. The volunteers are split into groups to do the tasks.
There are 26 volunteers planting trees. In 1 hour, 4 volunteers can plant 8 trees. How many trees can the volunteers plant at the park in 3 hours?
Each volunteer can plant :M-1: trees in 1 hour.
The volunteers can plant :M-2: trees in 3 hours.
In 4 hours, 6 volunteers can build 60% of the total benches needed. The volunteers will continue to work at the same rate until all the benches are built.

:ibox:• At this rate, how many more hours will the volunteers need to build the remaining benches?

• Show or explain your steps.

SubTopics: Giving quantitative measures of center (median and/or mean) and variability (interquartile range and/or mean absolute deviation), as well as describing any overall pattern and any striking deviations from the overall pattern with reference to the context in which the data were gathered.
Content: Use the information provided to answer Part A and Part B for this question.
The number of birds seen by a bird watcher each day for 30 days is recorded in a line plot.
problems/COG6M/media/13a.jpg
What is the mean number of birds seen by the bird watcher each day?
The bird watcher describes the center of the data set as the mean.
Which statement explains a reason the bird watcher would choose the mean to describe the center of the data set?

A.Choice: More than half of the recorded number of birds seen by the bird watcher are less than the mean.

B.Choice: The line plot showing the number of birds seen by the bird watcher is equally distributed.

C.Choice: There are about the same number of data points above and below the mean.

D.Choice: The mean is lower than all the data points.

SubTopics: Interpret and compute quotients of fractions, and solve word problems involving division of fractions by fractions, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.
Content: A serving of dog food is 5/8 cup. There are 3 3/4 cups of dog food in a bag.

:ibox:• Write an expression to determine how many servings of dog food are in the bag. Your expression must include fractions.

• Determine the number of servings of dog food in the bag. Show your work.

• Explain how to check your answer for the number of servings of dog food by using an equation with a different operation. Your equation must include fractions.
Expression: :FR-1:
Servings per bag: :FR-2:
Equation: :FR-3:

SubTopics: Add, subtract, multiply, and divide decimals to hundredths, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used.
Content: Use the information provided to answer Part A and Part B for question 6.
An artist is filling jars with sand of different colors and different amounts.

:ibox:• The artist divides the same amount of blue sand, the same amount of green sand, and the same amount of red sand into each of 20 jars.

• Each jar holds a total of 3.2 ounces of sand.

• The price of the sand is $0.17 per ounce.
problems/COG6M/media/15a.jpg

:ibox:• Determine the amount of red sand, in ounces, needed for all 20 jars.

• Write an equation or set of equations that can be used to find r, the amount of red sand, in ounces, the artist needs for all 20 jars.

• Write an equation (including r) to find p, the price of the red sand needed for all 20 jars.
Amount of sand (ounces): :FR-1:
Equation for r: :FR-2:
Equation for p: :FR-3:
The artist sells 12 of the 20 jars. The sand from the jars the artist did not sell will be poured into large jars that each hold 10 ounces when full.

:ibox:• Determine the fewest number of full large jars needed to hold the sand from the jars the artist did not sell.

• Write an equation or set of equations to model n, the total number of ounces of sand in the jars the artist did not sell.

• Write an equation (including n) to model j, the number of large jars needed to hold the sand from the jars the artist did not sell.
Fewest number of jars: :FR-1:
Equation for n: :FR-2:
Equation for j: :FR-3:

SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems by writing and solving equations of the form x ± p = q and px = q for cases in which p, q and x are all nonnegative rational numbers.
Content: Use the information provided to answer Part A and Part B for this question.
A store sells cherries for $3.70 per pound.
A person buys x pounds of cherries for $7.56.
Which equation can be used to find the number of pounds of cherries the person buys?

The store changes the price of the cherries. The equation 3.70 + p = 4.66 represents the relationship between the old and new prices of cherries, where p is the change in the price per pound of cherries.
What is the value of p in this equation?

SubTopics: Find a percent of a quantity as a rate per 100 (e.g., 30% of a quantity means 30/100 times the quantity); solve problems involving finding the whole, given a part and the percent.
Content: What is 45% of 320?

SubTopics: Find the volume of a right rectangular prism with fractional edge lengths by packing it with unit cubes of the appropriate unit fraction edge lengths, and show that the volume is the same as would be found by multiplying the edge lengths of the prism. Apply the formulas V = lwh and V = bh to find volumes of right rectangular prisms with fractional edge lengths in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: Answer Part A and Part B for this question.
A playground has a sandbox in the shape of a right rectangular prism. The length of the sandbox is 4 1/2 feet, and the width is 5 1/3 feet. The height of the sandbox is 1/2 foot.
problems/COG6M/media/18a.jpg
What is the volume, in cubic feet, of the sandbox?
Another area of the playground has a soft mat for safety. The area of the rectangular mat is 9 1/3 square feet. The mat is 1/4-foot thick.
What is the volume, in cubic feet, of the mat?

SubTopics: Use place value understanding to round decimals to any place.
Compare two decimals to thousandths based on meanings of the digits in each place, using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.
Content: Two students are comparing the decimals 13.310, 13.28, and 13.301.
Student A makes an error. He says that 13.28 > 13.301 because 8 is greater than 1.
Student B also makes an error. He says that 13.310 < 13.28 because 13.310 has a 3 in the tenths place and 2/10 is greater than 3/10.

:ibox:• Explain why the reasoning for Student A is incorrect.

• Explain why the reasoning for Student B is incorrect.

• Explain or show how to order the numbers from least to greatest.

• Find the sum of the three decimals rounded to the nearest tenth.

SubTopics: Apply the formulas V = l × w × h and V = b × h for rectangular prisms to find volumes of right rectangular prisms with whole-number edge lengths in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.

Use the additive nature of volume to find volumes of solid figures composed of two non-overlapping right rectangular prisms by adding the volumes of the non-overlapping parts, applying this technique to solve real-world problems.
Content: Answer Part A and Part B for this question.
An L-shaped pool is made of two right rectangular prisms. The figure shows a top view of this pool. The pool height is the same for the entire pool.
problems/COG6M/media/20a.jpg
The pool is filled with water to a height of 4 feet.

:ibox:• Create an equation or set of equations that can be used to find the volume, in cubic feet, of the pool.

• Explain how you created the equation or set of equations.

• Find the volume, in cubic feet, of the pool.
Equation: volume = :FR-1:
Volume of pool (cubic feet): :FR-2:
A different pool is in the shape of a right rectangular prism and has a volume of 192 cubic feet. The area of the base of the pool is 32 square feet.

:ibox:• Create an equation to find the height, in feet, of the water in the pool.

• Find the height, in feet, of the water in the pool. Show your work.
Equation: height = :FR-1:
Height of water (feet): :FR-2:
